climbs.name: Tax Man
climbs.fa: Tim Powell and Dan Ahlborn, April 1976

content.description: Definitely one of the most fun and exciting 5.10 pitches in the park. After a cruxy face start, the steep and excellent crack provides solid gear all the way up and a pump that makes reaching the bolted anchor a good challenge. With its excellent pro and steepness, this route makes a good first 5.10 lead.
content.protection: Full rack, small stoppers to 3.5" cam.

content.description:
In the large dihedral left - east of Tax Man, climb and stem the easy thin corner crack with a rotten hand crack on the right wall of the dihedral to the roof (ok pro in hand crack). Get good pro at the start of the roof then progressively harder under-clinging with thin edges for feet end at a desperate blind reach around the roof for a funky hand jam (crux). Mantle and finish the nice easy finger crack above.

Descend via Tax Man's single rope rappel anchors or scramble off west towards Copenhagen Wall.
content.protection:
Pro: light rack nuts and cams to 2.5 inches, include tiny cams. It is desperate to place pro along the roof with the smallest aliens or super small camelots. Alternatives are to go for it (scary) or place a yellow alien in the only good hand hold along the roof.

Gear belay 1-3" cams.

content.description: Climb Tax Man to just below the final bit and traverse left 15 feet along a horizontal crack to finish the fun finger crack bit of Tax Free.  This is a fun alternative finish and just about as hard as the final bit of Tax Man.  Take care with the loose lip along the traverse.
content.protection: 2" cam for traverse, stoppers or 1-2" cams for the final finger crack and long slings.  1-3" cams for gear belay.
content.location: Descent traverse over west to Tax Man's rappel anchors, single 50 meter rope rappel to ground.

content.description: Short but strenuous, this dihedral to roof features a wide hand/fist crack in the back with strenuous movement as you work to keep the weight off your arms. A good selection of wide gear and a go-for-it attitude help on this route. Note: this route favors those with larger hands/fists.
content.location:
Starts down and left from

Alf's Arete

at an obvious left-facing corner system.

climbs.name: Serbian Stairway
climbs.fa: Sonja Djuricin and Todd Gordon, January 2007

content.description:
Solo 40ft up to ledge with a bolt. Make crux move off ledge to left-facing flake. Surmount flake and continue up easy, heavily featured arete to steep headwall arete. Rap off from the

Tax Man

anchors.
content.protection: 1 bolt + standard rack, need big cam for anchor.
content.location:
Starts 12 feet to the right of

Tax Man

.

climbs.name: Nuclear Waste
climbs.fa: Mike Lechlinski, Mari Gingery & Randy Vogel, 1982

content.description: Some 5.10- face climbing past a bolt (crux) on crunchy edges leads up and right to a crack. This crack is low angle and uninteresting, so place a piece or two and then bust out left into the steeper thin crack that splits the center of the buttress. Edges and the occasional fingerlock will see you through until the crack opens up higher. Belay from a 2 bolt anchor shared with Alf's Arete .11a.
content.protection: Bolt (3/8"), thin wires, maybe brass, and some gear to 2" perhaps.
content.location:
Just right of the famous

Alf's Arete

.11a, starting on the right side of the large yucca at it's base. Rappel from 2 bolt anchor. Easily TR'ed after doing Alf's Arete.

content.description: Start far to the right of Taxman bellow the obvious crack. Climb up ten feet then traversing left to a hands crack which leads to a staircase and the base of the final offwidth sized crack.
content.protection: Standard rack with multiples of threes and fours. You'll need at least two BD three or fours to build an anchor to protect the follower. There are rap rings located at the top, fifteen feet climbers right of the top out.

content.description:
An exciting boulder start over a hole in the boulders gains the crack proper where face climbing, liebacking and even some jamming will keep you moving upwards on this testy little pitch.

Once at the ledge finish up a short easy crack or, better yet, cut slightly left and finish up the two bolts of

H & R Block

(5.6) and belay from the bolts atop that route.

The climbing is fun and challenging, but the amount of real climbing to approach ratio makes this much less appealing than the nearby Tax Man; starting at ground level and climbing up through the hole increases the length and makes it more interesting.

The easiest descent is to head up and over the back and then circle back left to reach the bolted anchors atop

Tax Man

.
content.protection: Gear to 2.5 inches including wires, 2 bolts, bolted anchor/rap
content.location:
Scramble up boulders past

Mr. Bunny Vs. Six Unknown Agents

to reach this short but engaging crack.

climbs.name: Mr. Bunny Vs. Six Unknown Agents

content.description: From Tax Man scramble up the wall to belay on a huge chockstone directly under the crack.  I found the climbing to be better than it looked from below.  About 30' up a spicy traverse to the right will get your attention.  I gave the climb two stars as we combined it with H&R Block for a nice 100' pitch.
content.protection: Medium and large gear work for this crack.  Will gobble a few nuts too.

content.description: A short but pleasant thin crack that's hidden from view and actually facing the IRS Wall.
content.location: Located in the descent gully that's at the far right side of the crag.

content.description:
This short, but highly featured, face directly above

Mr. Bunny Vs. Six Unknown Agents

(5.8) is a fun alternative to the upper portion of that route or

Mr. Bunny's Refund Check

(5.10a). One star out of five, maybe two if linked with one of the " Mr. Bunny" routes.

climbs.name: Bullet Head
climbs.fa: Chris Breemer, Pol Anderson, Bill Willey & Ola Nilssan, 1/90

content.description: Climb a crack in the Tax Free dihedral to the right arete, pass two bolts with balancy crux moves above the second bolt, follow Tax Free's nice easy finger crack above.
content.protection: Assorted nuts and cams to 2" and two bolts.  1-3" cams for belay.
content.location: Starts in the dihedral of Tax Free, left of Tax Man.  Descent is traverse west over to Tax Man's rappel anchors and one single rope rappel.

climbs.name: Commander Cody
climbs.fa: Todd Gordon and Cody Dolnick, Nov. 1986

content.description: an unpleasant crack and face climb on very poor rock

climbs.name: Bloody Tax Break
climbs.fa: Mike Forkash, Steve Gerberding and Jay Goodwin (aka Punkman) 2/83

content.description: To find Bloody Tax Break, approach IRS wall as for Taxman.  Bloody Tax Break ascends the thin fingers-to-tips crack about 3-4 meters to the right hand side of Taxman, near or on the right hand arete of that same wall.  The precise way to approach is difficult, but more or less consists of walking towards IRS wall, approaching it's lower left hand side, then clambering up and over boulders towards it's upper right hand side until you encounter these two stunning fingercracks in a flat wall capped by a roof just below the top. Climb up to the crack at the right hand side.  Near the ground, you can step to the right and climb easy terrain with the crack or step left and make an eliminate problem out of the crack, climbing a better line on better rock. As the climb continues, a bulge on the right side of the arete forces those on the right into the harder climbing for the crux anyway. There are two cruxes on this route, of a similar nature to that of Taxman, but perhaps a little harder; one 1/2 way up, and one switching cracks to the right at the small roof as the original line disappears. This climb would get more stars if the rock were more solid.
content.protection: The pro on this route is reasonable at the crux, and below that can be had with patience. I seriously recommend taking some thin cams or slider nuts if you like to put in a lot of gear or are not really solid at 5.10-.  Fixed anchors up and left 10' above 'Taxman' provide a convenient belay and rap off.

climbs.name: Atomic Pile
climbs.fa: Randy Vogel and Maria Cranor, April 1980

content.description: Climb up the crack behind the flake across patina flakes to another crack.
content.location: To the right of Alf's Arete, starts behind a large partially detached flake.

content.description: On the left edge of the IRS wall is an almost vertical arete with 7 bolts. This is Alf's Arete. Technical edging and very thin holds characterise this face climb. The first bolt is a little high, and you definitely don't want to blow it before clipping it. The finish, though quite slabby, is run out and forces you to keep your concentration high.
content.protection: 7 bolts. First one is kind of high off the ground. Anchor on top.
